children.label: b47595316
children.title: University of Edinburgh Survey on Research Culture

children.label: b47595672
children.text:
Information for participants: Version 1.5, 13th July 2020

Introduction

In February the Wellcome Trust (WT) published the findings of their survey on research cultures across institutions. Over 2000 UK based academics completed the survey, which had some reassuring findings, but also contained some cause for concern.

We invite you to participate in a research study about research culture at the University of Edinburgh. This study is being conducted by Malcolm Macleod, Academic Lead for Research Improvement and Research Integrity; Sara Shinton, Head of Researcher Development at the Institute for Academic Development, Bridget Mellifont, Policy and Projects Officer; and Lorna Thomson, Director of Research. 

Purposes of the study

Part 1: As one of our first steps in responding to the challenge of improving our research culture we are now seeking your views, using the same questions that were used in the Wellcome Trust survey. This will allow us to see areas where we have substantial room for improvement, and also if there are areas where sharing our good practice may be helpful for other institutions.

Potential routes to improvement might include for changing criteria for promotion and the use of research metrics; ensuring that University policies which influence research culture are appropriate and, crucially, that they are being implemented; providing opportunities for researchers to reflect more on research culture; and celebrating individuals and departments for their contribution to improving research.

We appreciate that COVID may have shaped you recent experiences of our research culture - and Part 2 deals specifically with this - but in Part 1, we are interested in your experience of our research culture in normal times.

Part 2: We are conducting this survey in the middle of a global pandemic, and we appreciate that it is a worrying time. Knowing more about how this has affected you and your work is important to us as we plan for the future. Specifically, we are interested in whether some groups have been differently affected.

Finally, we see surveys like this as an important tool as we focus on improving our research culture, so that we might see if improvement is actually happening. To inform future survey designs we are also collecting information on how best to enhance survey response rates, and on whether it is possible to get the same information from fewer questions. The findings from this aspect of the survey may be published as a research article.

Why have I been invited to take part?

We are interested in the views and experiences of all members of the research community, including researchers and research technicians at all career stages, research students, research professional staff, and others, and we have tried to identify email addresses for all of these groups. 

Do I need to participate?

No - participation is entirely voluntary. If you do decide to take part you are free to withdraw at any time by exiting the survey. Deciding not to take part or withdrawing from the study will not affect you or your employment in any way. Please note that as responses are anonymous, once you submit the survey it will not be possible to withdraw your data.

What will taking part involve?

If you decide to take part we will ask you to provide consent on the next page. You will then be ask to complete an online survey, which will take around 15 minutes to complete. IIf you do not want to complete the survey in a single session it is possible to save your progress (the "Finish Later" buttons) and return later.

What will we do with the information you provide?

We will download survey data from this online platforn to secure storage in the Edinburgh DataStore, with access restricted to members of the immediate research team. Email addresses will be removed, and data processed for analysis to address our research questions.

Research Culture questions (Part 1): We will report the findings to the Research Ethics and Integrity Review group, the Research Policy Group and the University Executive. They will help us identify those aspects of research culture where we should focus our immediate attention. The report will also be disseminated to the University community. With the UK Reproducibility Network we are working with other institutions who are interested in improving their research cultures, and to enhance transparency and trust we commit to open sharing of both the report and an appropriately anonymised study dataset.

COVID related questions (Part 2): We will report the findings to the Research Ethics and Integrity Review group, the Research Policy Group and the University Executive. They will inform our COVID research recovery strategy. The same principles of transparency and trust apply, and so we again commit to open sharing of an appropriately anonymised study dataset.

We will analyse questionnaire response rates and questionnaire responses to inform the design and execution of future surveys of this type.

Please note that you will not be identifiable in any of the reports and datasets produced.

Benefits of participation

By deepening our understanding of our research culture, we can set out a strategy to improve it, which should be of benefit to us all.

In appreciation of your efforts there will be a random lottery. To process this - because the responses are otherwise anonymous - we would need your email address. So if you would like to be entered for this lottery, please provide your email address on the final page.

Costs and risks of participating

The questionnaire is long; we estimate it will take upwards of 15 minutes to complete. We have chosen, in our first survey of research culture, to ask all the questions asked in the WT survey. However, we believe that we can use your responses to validate a smaller set of questions, which we can repeat on an annual basis to identify changes in research culture. So your responses to this time consuming questionnaire will help us make the next one less time consuming!

You may find answering some of the questions upsetting, but we expect that this would not be different from the kinds of things you discuss with family or friends. We signpost sources of help and advice through the survey. You may skip any questions you don’t want to answer and you may discontinue the survey at any time. 

Please do not include any personally identifiable information in the free text response fields, as this will be discarded. If there are issues you wish to discuss, please contact malcolm.macleod@ed.ac.uk.

Data Protection and Confidentiality

Your data will be processed in accordance with Data Protection Law. All information collected about you will be kept strictly confidential.

We do not record your IP address. We collect some demographic information to understand if research culture, and the COVID pandemic, are experienced differently by people in different groups. You are not required to provide this information, and your other survey responses will still be included in the analysis. We will not provide any analyses aggregated by demographic characteristics where there are fewer the 10 respondents in a category; these will be aggregated into larger groupings. Email addresses provided for the lottery will be separated from other survey responses at the first stage of processing, and files where the email address is linked to responses will be deleted.

At the end of the study we will retain a version of the dataset - including demographic information but excluding email addresses - in secure long term storage in Edinburgh DataVault. We will retain these files for at least 15 years, and they may be shared with other researchers for future ethically approved research.

If you have any questions, concerns or comments please contact malcolm.macleod@ed.ac.uk.

children.label: b47596904
children.text:
Ethical approval

This survey has been considered by and received a favourable opinion from the College of Arts, Humanities and Social Sciences Research Ethics Service

children.label: b47596872
children.text:
Privacy statement

Any email address provided will be removed from the dataset prior to data processing and used only for the allocation of the study incentive. Your IP address is not recorded.

Where responses are aggregated according to demographic details, these will only be presented where there are at least 10 people in the smallest category, so that individual responses cannot be identified. 

Any publication or dissemination of the survey findings will specifically exclude information about you which could link you to the responses you have given. 

If you have any concerns about the data collected in this survey contact the University Data Protection Officer, details at https://www.ed.ac.uk/records-management/about/data-protection-officer.

children.label: b49247370
children.text:
Study Contacts

If you have any questions about the study please contact Malcolm Macleod on malcolm.macleod@ed.ac.uk

If you would like to speak to someone independent of the study about the study please contact Emily Sena on Emily.Sena@ed.ac.uk

If you would like to make a complaint about the study please contact Bridget Colam on Bridget.Colam@ed.ac.uk

children.label: b49218879
children.text:
1. I confirm that I have read and understood the Information for Participants (Version 1.5 dated 13 July 2020). 
  2. I have considered the information provided, and have had the opportunity to email the survey organiser with any questions; any such questions have been answered to my satisfaction
  3. I understand that my participation is voluntary and that I can ask to withdraw at any time without giving a reason and without my employment or legal rights being affected. 
  4. I understand that my anonymised data, including any demographic information I provide, will be stored for a minimum of 15 years and may be used in future ethically approved research.
  5. I understand that my anonymised data, not including demographic information, will be stored in a publically available dataset
  6. I agree to take part in the above study.

children.label: b48893766
children.text: In this first part, we are most interested in your experience of our research culture in normal times. We appreciate that it may be difficult to disentangle this from your recent experiences during the COVID pandemic, but ask you to try your best!

children.label: b48893992
children.title: Part 2: Impact of the COVID pandemic

children.label: b48894223
children.text: Here we are interested specifically in your experiences during the COVID pandemic, in how it has impacted on your work, and how you, your colleagues and the University have been able to respond.

children.label: b47600380
children.text: To what extent has your research activity been affected by the COVID pandemic?

children.label: b47600381
children.text: Not at all

children.label: b47596356
children.text:
Answers to these questions will not be included in any published summary data. Please do not feel at all obliged to answer these questions.

The reason we are interested in knowing more about you is so that we can establish the different ways in which specific groups within our community experience research culture.

children.label: b47596705
children.text:
That's it! You made it to the end.

Thank you very much for your time and patience. Summary results will be considered by the Research Ethics and Integrity Review Group and the Research Policy Group, and the results, and the University's response, will be published later in the year.

If you are concerned about any issues of research culture or research integrity, details of who to contact are given at https://www.ed.ac.uk/research-office/research-integrity/need-help, or you can contact the Acdemic Lead for Research Improvement and Research Integrity, malcolm.macleod@ed.ac.uk.
